comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think they are from left to right - Sir Bertram Stevens (who also has a 'Drive' in the Royal National Park named after him) - adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A120089b.htm Margaret, Lady Wakehurst and Lord Wakehurst, Governor of NSW 1937-1946. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_de_Vere_Loder,_2nd_Baron_Wakeh... But I could be wrong!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I think you could be wrong about Premier Stevens at least, who looked like this in 1939, the year according to the Wollongong City Council website Lady Wakehurst Drive was completed: 'During the depression years the State Government created a road building program to support many unemployed men. One of the major construction projects was the building of Lady Wakehurst Drive through the Royal National Park in 1937-1939. The men were divided into teams that worked alternative weeks which allowed families to live on a weekly wage over a fortnight. (Fletcher & Rook, 1985).' This is definitely the unveiling. You can see the line the flag was pulled back along. I dare say there would be a plaque with the precise day and the officials present ... Day trip anyone?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Ok, the people we have here are L to R Joe Cahill, Lady Wakehurst, Lord Wakehurst. The event was the unveiling of the Lady Wakehurst Drive and Lady Wakehurst look-out seat by the Governor, Lord Wakehurst. The date was Tuesday 15 May, 1945. The road may have been constructed in '37-'39 but it was not dedicated as thus until 1945 to commemmorate the term of office of the Governor. Here's the Sydney Morning Herald piece from the day: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2627459 That piece does not specifically say the Joe Cahill assisted with the unveiling, but it does say that he there on the day to open McKell Drive. Comparison with other photos of Cahill identify him. Photographs of John Joseph (Joe) Cahill here: www.nswalp.com/labor-people/12/96/joe-cahill and here: adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A130376b.htm?hilite=cahill Lord Wakehurst: adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A160554b.htm?hilite=wakehurst

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Well done BobMeade with Joe Cahill.   I had a suspicion it was 1940s with the style of the cars and Her Ladyship's Dead Animal over her shoulder, very inappropriate for a day out in the Royal National Park.  My grandmother used to have one - it must be one of the oddest fashion statements ever!

comment.author: 57407120@N07
comment._content:
And just a bit of trivia The ex Sydney & Manly Ferry "Lady Wakehurst" is just about to leave Australia for a new life as a Solomon Islands Ferry.

A friend, who is the new owner will be pointing her due East later this week and leaving Australian waters most likely for the last time.

Ric
